Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53286-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
 
Strengthening Knowledge Alliance for Innovation, 
Technology, and Regional Cooperation 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
ERCI  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration Division 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Development

Department (ERCD)

ERCD

territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  strengthen  development 
research partnerships on the themes of innovation, technology, and regional cooperation by 
collaborating  with  policy  research  institutions  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  It  will  promote  new 
knowledge generated from these research works by organizing technical workshops, policy 
dialogues, and networking among government and research institutions. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the 2019 annual work program for the Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to (i) undertake 
and  disseminate  policy  research  and  knowledge  generation  on  development  and  regional 
economic  cooperation;  and  (ii)  collaborate  and  network  with  international  organizations, 
government  agencies,  and  research  institutes.1 It  will  also  support  ADB’s  Strategy  2030 
Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–2024 by 
contributing to the improvement of policy formulation and project design on regional public goods.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Innovation and technological change are rapidly transforming the economic landscape 
across Asia and the Pacific. Advancement of digital computing technologies and innovations such 
as mobile communications, artificial intelligence, big data analysis, and robotics are changing the 
way entities produce, transact, and interact in the markets. Business processes have also 
benefitted from a productivity boost through the emergence of the platform economy ─ digital 
structures that enable economic and social activities ─ and e-commerce.3 Technologies have 
allowed many economic activities to transcend borders at much lower costs. 
 
4.  Along with digitalization, increasing economic transactions, and interaction of people 
comes  increased  complexity  in  economic  activities,  cross-border  interdependence,  and 
externalities.4 The  share  of  cross-border  services  and  financial  transactions  using  digital 
platforms has expanded, possibly adding complexity to the policy and regulatory environment. 
While new technologies such as digital identity, artificial intelligence, and block chain technologies 
have the potential to promote efficiency and transparency in such economic activities and 
markets, the digital economy that transcends borders is generating new risks and vulnerabilities, 
which  may  simultaneously  affect  multiple  countries.  These  risks  can  be  in  the  forms  of 
cyberattacks and transnational crimes resulting from the increased digital transactions, the lack 
of protection for the rights of the digital or online workforce, or financial contagion from increased 
cross-border financial transactions. The persistence of a wide digital divide within and across 
countries continues to pose a threat to inclusive growth. 
 
5.  Generating policy-relevant knowledge on the implications of innovation and technological 
change on regional cooperation is essential, especially in the following areas: (i) developing the 
conceptual framework to understand and model the economic impact of ongoing innovation and 
technological changes in Asia and the Pacific; (ii) assessing the economic potential and policy 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 December 2019.  
2  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration (2019–
2024). Manila. 
3  ADB. 2018. News Release. ADB Supports Digital Technologies for Innovative Development Solutions. Manila. 
https://www.adb.org/news/adb-supports-digital-technologies-innovative-development-solutions 
4  ADB. 2018. Asian Economic Integration Report 2018. Towards Optimal Provision of Regional Public Goods in Asia 
and the Pacific. Manila (pp. 122–177).

2 
challenges for adopting a particular technology or group of technologies; and (iii) identifying the 
policy implications and recommendations, both at national and regional levels. 
 
6.  There is limited research that evaluates the impacts and implications of innovation and 
technology on the regional economy because of several reasons. Technology-related research 
necessitates  technical  expertise  and  exploration  of  new  data  sources  and  research 
methodologies, and these are often limited in developing member country (DMC) research 
institutions. Regional and cross-country research also requires resources, networks, coordination, 
and trust, while the supply can be limited because of externalities and the public-good nature of 
the knowledge. 
 
7.  This TA will respond to the need for building knowledge and strengthening knowledge 
sharing on the impacts and implications of innovation and technology on regional economies and 
policy implications for regional cooperation. It will build on ERCD’s growing portfolio of broad and 
specific technology-focused research on the regional economic agenda, such as e-commerce, 
financial  technology  and  sustainable  finance,  digital  trade,  technology  and  human  capital 
development, and the movement of people.5 The TA promotes innovative research that uses 
novel techniques and data sources, such as big data that can elucidate the effects, challenges, 
and opportunities of existing and emerging technologies. Cross-sectional issues on economic, 
social, and environmental aspects of technological innovation could also be part of the research 
areas. 
 
8.  This  TA  will  encourage  participation  and  collaboration  among  regional  research 
institutions,  including  members  of  the  ADB–Asian  Think  Tank  Network,  to  tap  advanced 
knowledge and expertise by forging strong international alliances. The TA team will conduct 
research focusing on technology in the regional context, which also contributes to improving the 
research capacity of the think tanks in ADB’s DMCs. A past ADB project has demonstrated that 
providing a platform for knowledge generation and sharing can inspire and challenge younger 
think tanks to improve their research and institutional capacities.6 An ongoing TA implemented by 
ERCD engaged with these think tanks, resulting in research work in the areas of aging and labor 
mobility and trade and global value chains, with impact on policy-making in some of the DMCs.7 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: policy formulation and project design in 
ADB’s DMCs enhanced, and inclusiveness of regional cooperation and integration projects 
strengthened.8 The TA will have the following outcome: knowledge on innovation, technology, 
and regional cooperation improved and knowledge alliance enhanced.9 
 
 
5  ADB. 2018. Embracing the E-commerce Revolution in Asia and the Pacific. Manila; ADB. 2018. Harnessing 
Technology for More Inclusive Sustainable Finance in Asia and the Pacific. Manila; ADB. 2019. Asia Pacific Trade 
Facilitation Report. Manila; and ADB. 2018. Tapping Technology to Maximize the Longevity Dividend in Asia. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2019. Completion Report: Provision of Knowledge Products and Services to Developing Member Countries 
through Systematic Knowledge Sharing. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Regional Cooperation and Integration Knowledge Partnerships 
and Research Network in Asia and the Pacific. Manila. https://www.adb.org/projects/51291-001/main. 
8  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration (2019–
2024). Manila. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output  1:  Study  proposals  from  developing  member  country  development 
researchers submitted and collaborative research on three development topics conducted. 
The TA will implement three joint research projects on the topics of innovation, technology, and 
regional cooperation, in collaboration with development research institutions. One inception 
workshop and two technical workshops will be conducted per theme to assess research progress. 
Draft research papers will be presented to a group of experts. Call for papers will be issued prior 
to the policy dialogue workshop in partnership with regional research institutions. Presentations 
in other regional forums, such as the Asia–Pacific Economic Cooperation, the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations, and all of ADB’s flagship regional cooperation and integration programs, 
will be sought to expand the reach of the research findings.  
 
11.  Output 2: Development researchers from developing member country think tanks 
improved research capacities and deepened knowledge on the themes. Workshops and 
forums will be conducted for each topic to provide a platform for knowledge exchange, in-depth 
discussions, and discourse on innovative findings and/or ideas and policy solutions. Participants 
will be encouraged to discuss ongoing or proposed research works relevant to the themes. They 
are expected to benefit from the comments of like-minded experts. 
 
12.  Output 3: Policy papers and reports published and disseminated. Policy briefs, 
including policy recommendations, will be generated from the research papers, and will be 
disseminated electronically to as wide a regional audience as possible and through collaboration 
with other ADB projects. The results of the studies will also be shared and discussed with ADB’s 
regional departments. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Regional Cooperation and Integration Division (ERCI) of 
ERCD will be responsible for supervising and managing consultants, procuring goods, organizing 
workshops, providing staff as appropriate to act as resource persons in workshops, and achieving 
the desired outputs. Collaboration with ADB’s regional departments will be sought as much as 
possible for alignment of research priorities and dissemination of studies. 
 
15.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2019–November 2021 
Executing agency  Asian Development Bank (ADB), Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Division 
Consultantsa  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual: individual  International expertise  $181,000 
selection  (14 person-months) 
Individual: individual  National expertise (77  $192,000 
selection  person-months)

4 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Procurementb  To be procured by ADB 
Request for quotations  4 contracts  $6,000 
Disbursement  The technical assistance resources will be disbursed following 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
a  ADB will consider lump-sum payments, output-based contracts, and framework contracts for individual consulting 
services. 
b  Procurement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
16. Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions
and/or staff instructions.10 ADB will commission the international consultants to conduct research
on chosen topics. ERCI will work with the international consultants to produce research papers.
National consultants will include project analysts, publications and/or website developers, and an
event organizer. ADB will engage international experts, which may include ADB staff, as resource
persons to present or facilitate discussion at seminars and other events. Engaging individual
consultants is deemed more beneficial to ADB since the desired sector and/or country expertise
and qualifications of individual consultants are varied. It will be difficult to find a firm that
specializes in the range of topics and countries that the TA will cover.
17. An ERCI staff team comprising two international staff members (one acting as the project
leader and the other as alternate project leader), one national officer, one operations coordinator,
and one operations assistant will oversee and manage TA implementation.
18. Knowledge  partnerships.  Although  not  envisioned  for  this  TA,  should  it  become
necessary to enter into knowledge partnership agreements of an intellectual and/or advisory
nature  with  international  organizations,  academic  institutions,  and/or  think  tanks,  any  such
partnership will follow the Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships
under Technical Assistance Operations.11 The partnership agreements will clearly delineate roles
and disbursements.
19. ADB’s procurement. The purchase of software and/or statistical databases will follow the
ADB Procurement Policy and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended
from time to time). Where applicable, the TA team will coordinate with ADB’s Procurement,
Portfolio and Financial Management Department and Office of the General Counsel before
purchasing datasets and signing data use agreements with DMC statistical agencies and third-
party database providers. Disbursements under this TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
20. Social media and websites. The TA team will maintain the website of an existing relevant
project (footnote 7).12 Before project closing, it will explore other sources of financing for website
maintenance if there is strong demand for the website’s continued existence. In the absence of
such demand, the website will be automatically deactivated 3 months after the TA completion
date.
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
11 ADB. 2017. Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance 
Operations. Manila. 
12 The project team will collaborate with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and Technology to ensure that proper 
ADB information technology security controls are implemented.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Knowledge Alliance for Innovation, Technology, and Regional Cooperation, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Study proposals from developing member country development researchers submitted and 
collaborative research on three development topics conducted 
1.1 Hold inception workshops (Themes: February 2020 [first], October 2020 [second], February 2021 
[third]). 
1.2 Carry out collaborative research with knowledge institutions or experts (Themes: April 2020 [first], 
December 2020 [second], April 2021 [third]). 
1.3 Submit draft research (Themes: August 2020 [first], May 2021 [second], July 2021 [third]). 
1.4 Finalize research output (Themes: October 2020 [first], July 2021 [second], October 2021 [third]). 
 
2. Development researchers from developing member country think tanks improved research 
capacities and deepened knowledge on the themes 
2.1 Hold technical workshops to discuss research progress (August 2020, April 2021, August 2021). 
2.2 Hold policy dialogues (October 2020, July 2021, October 2021). 
2.3 Hold dissemination workshops (January 2021, September 2021, December 2021). 
 
3. Policy papers and reports printed and disseminated 
3.1 Publish policy papers (January 2021, September 2021, December 2021). 
3.2 Publish book and/or report volume (November 2021). 
3.3 Maintain and update website (January 2020 onward). 
 
TA Management Activities 
Hire consultants (January–February 2020, October–November 2020, January–February 2021, or as 
needed). 
Procure information and knowledge services (as needed).

Not applicable
